bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 31, 1923

div1.p: Carter writes that he agrees with the Pareja report regarding yellow fever in Ecuador.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 31, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
March 31, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Referring to the papers from Dr. Pareja, enclosed with
yours of the 29th.:

1/__In my judgement the evidence for the existence of yellow
fever in Ecuador is very slight.
I have said this since I saw the distribution of cases.

2/ __ I suspect that Pareja's explanation of the report of
these cases, as given in the last paragraph of the Memoran-
dum, is the correct one. This I also stated some time ago.

3/ __ The presence of the troops in the city for five months
(and three years accumulation of serranos and babies) with no
yellow fever reported would be well-nigh, or quite, absolute
proof that there was none in Guayaquil--if he had his former
Stegomyia index. A low index, naturally, renders it less con-
vincing--but safer.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
